feed.title: NewsTracker: facebook
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Mom uses Facebook to apologize for rude daughters
entry.summary: "My son later told me, much to my humiliation and embarrassment, that my girls were rude and obnoxious during the movie. The woman I'm looking for addressed them and asked them to be quiet and they were disrespectful," Wood wrote on her Facebook post.

entry.title: Photo of Myanmarâ€™s reclusive former dictator surfaces on Facebook
entry.summary: The Facebook photo garnered more than 4,500 "likes", including one by Ye Htut, Myanmar's information minister.

entry.title: Facebook talks up need for virtual reality, big tech bets
entry.summary:
While virtual reality headsets such as the Oculus Rift suggest video games and entertainment, the gadgets could transform how people communicate on Facebook, they said.

Events such as a birthday party or a child's first bike ride could be shared on Facebook so that users in different parts of the world felt as if they were taking part.

Facebook had never made clear its virtual reality plans, Vlada Bortnik, the founder of app-maker Happy Bits, said at the conference.

Facebook and Google Inc are building Internet-beaming satellites and drones to connect billions of people who lack Internet access, as the companies compete to become the go-to online hub for consumers and marketers.

entry.title: Facebook moves ahead toward Internet drone air fleet
entry.summary: "Aircraft like these will help connect the whole world because they can affordably serve the 10 percent of the world's population that live in remote communities without existing Internet infrastructure," Zuckerberg said in a post on his Facebook timeline.

entry.title: Facebook lets friends send cash over Messenger
entry.summary: Last summer Facebook hired PayPal President David Marcus to run all of its messaging products.

entry.title: Penn State frat suspended for year over nude Facebook pics
entry.summary:
"The evidence offered by the Facebook postings is appalling, offensive and inconsistent with the university community's values and expectations," Damon Sims, Penn State's vice president for student affairs, said in a news release.

Facebook was contacted to disable the site and to obtain more information for the investigation, Robb said.

entry.title: Women pictured on Penn St. frat's Facebook page talk to cops
entry.summary:
(AP) - Some women pictured nude or seminude in photos posted to a Penn State fraternity's secret Facebook page have come forward, and some frat members are now cooperating with an ongoing criminal investigation, police said.

The warrant targeted an invitation-only Facebook page run by the fraternity members that showed pictures of women, some apparently passed out or sleeping, nude or partially dressed, and screenshots of text messages discussing sex with the women, among other things.

entry.title: Facebook clarifies guidelines on acceptable posts
entry.summary:
The new guidelines say Facebook members should use their "authentic name," a move that appears to head off criticism from people who used stage or performance names instead of their legal name.

In October Facebook said it would ease its "real names" policy that prompted drag queen performers to quit the social network and sparked wider protests in the gay community and beyond.

Facebook's new guidelines said it would remove content, disable accounts and work with law enforcement "when we believe that there is a genuine risk of physical harm or direct threats to public safety."

The move comes with Facebook and other social media struggling with defining acceptable content and freedom of expression.

"This is particularly challenging for issues such as hate speech. Hate speech has always been banned on Facebook, and in our new community standards, we explain our efforts to keep our community free from this kind of abusive language."

entry.title: Fin24.com | Facebook bets on Messenger app for e-commerce
entry.summary: "I think that they are interested in letting people know that Facebook is not a single app company, it is an app constellation."

entry.title: Facebook's Messenger app to mix business with more pleasure
entry.summary:
Facebook is trying to mold its Messenger app into a more versatile communications channel as smartphones create new ways for people to connect with friends and businesses beyond the walls of the company's ubiquitous social network.

CEO Mark Zuckerberg delivers the keynote address during the Facebook F8 Developer Conference Wednesday, March 25, 2015, in San Francisco.

entry.title: Facebook's Messenger app to mix business with more pleasure
entry.summary:
The push to diversify Messenger addresses a potential threat to Facebook's ubiquitous social network posed by a variety of mobile messaging maps offering more intimate and direct ways to connect with friends.

The growing popularity of mobile messaging, though, could result in less time spent on social networks, a shift that would give Facebook fewer opportunities to learn about its users' interests and show the digital ads that make most of the company's money.

Analysts widely expect Facebook to begin showing ads with Messenger as people spend more time in the app to do different things, though the Menlo Park, California, company hasn't revealed plans to turn the app into a marketing vehicle.

entry.title: Facebook's Messenger app to mix business with more pleasure
entry.summary:
Younger people, in particular, are increasingly using a wide range of mobile messaging apps to communicate while spending less time broadcasting their activities on Facebook's more expansive social network.

Thanks largely to its Facebook ties, Messenger already has more than 600 million users, Zuckerberg said.

Facebook's revenue last year surged 58 percent to $12.5 billion, a performance that has enabled the company's stock price to more than double from its initial public offering price of $38 in 2012.

entry.title: Facebook's Messenger app to mix business with more pleasure
Facebook opens Messenger app up to ESPN, J.J. Abrams [Photos]
entry.summary: The upgraded Facebook Messenger app will add a wider range of video, voice and location-sharing capabilities, the company announced at its F8 developers' conference Wednesday.

entry.title: Facebook Inc expands Messenger app features â€˜to reinvent the way people are communicatingâ€™
entry.summary:
Facebook unveiled the new features at its annual developer conference in San Francisco, for the first time allowing developers to create apps that function inside the Messenger app, which has more than 600 million users.

Forty different apps will be available on Messenger in the coming days, allowing users of the service to send each other sports clips and animations, Facebook said.

entry.title: Facebook's Messenger app adding more ways to connect
entry.summary: To pull it off, Facebook Inc. is opening Messenger so outside programmers can build features tailored for the service.

entry.title: Facebook's Messenger app adding more ways to connect
entry.summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg touted the Messenger expansion Wednesday during his opening speech at a two-day conference for developers in San Francisco.

entry.title: Facebook said in talks with publishers on hosting content
entry.summary:
Facebook is in talks with the New York Times, BuzzFeed and National Geographic about hosting their articles or videos directly on the social network, the New York Times reported Monday.

Last month, Facebook's chief product officer, Chris Cox, said at a media conference that the social network had early conversations with publishers about hosting their content.

entry.title: What to expect from Zuckerberg at Facebook's F8
entry.summary: Facebook is in talks with several media organizations to host articles within the social network, according to the New York Times.

entry.title: Fugitive's dad tells why he thinks son fled in Facebook case
Dad: Fugitive son afraid his Facebook trial wouldn't be fair
entry.summary:
Carmine Ceglia said his son found it "really upsetting" when he was told lawyers hired by Facebook were working with prosecutors on the criminal case against him.

Prosecutors say Ceglia added a page to a two-page contract he signed in 2003 with Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg to make it seem he was entitled to be part owner of the Menlo Park, California social media giant.

entry.title: Facebook to host news from New York Times, BuzzFeed
Family of alleged Facebook fraud fugitive to forfeit bail: U.S. judge
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - The family of a New York man who became a fugitive after being criminally charged with trying to defraud Facebook Inc founder Mark Zuckerberg out of half of the social media company was ordered on Tuesday to forfeit his bail.

Ceglia's father Carmine said he did not know where his son was but expressed sympathy for him, suggesting that Facebook's principal lawyer was unduly influencing federal prosecutors.

entry.title: Family of alleged Facebook fraud fugitive to forfeit bail: U.S. judge
entry.summary: Facebook's lawyer had no immediate comment.

entry.title: Afghan police official fired for mob-killing Facebook comment
entry.summary: Hashmat Stanekzai, the spokesman for Kabul's police chief, was also fired on Tuesday for statements made on his personal Facebook page the day after the killing, Olomi said.

entry.title: Man sentenced in Facebook threat case tied to larger debate
entry.summary: In the case the judge referred to, a Massachusetts man was arrested for posting "Put Wings On Pigs" on his Facebook page in December.

entry.title: Ferguson Facebook case part of debate about online threats
entry.summary:
When Anthony Elonis' wife left him, he vented on his Facebook page by posting violent threats against her in the form of rap lyrics.

A Nevada man was indicted in January for posting threats on Facebook to kill an African American police officer.

entry.title: California woman sues Facebook for discrimination
entry.summary: Facebook maintains it did not mistreat Hong.

entry.title: Man who threatened Ferguson officer must stay off Facebook
Ferguson Facebook case part of debate about online threats
entry.summary:
He noted that in a separate case - the recent killings of two New York police officers - the gunman posted Facebook threats before shooting the officers.

Abdul-Jabbaar pleaded guilty Feb. 2 for posting a threat against Wilson on Facebook that included a call to "give back those bullets that Police Officer Darren Wilson fired into the body of Mike Brown."

entry.title: Cash Transfer For Facebook Messenger
entry.summary: "We use secure systems that encrypt the connection between you and Facebook as well as your card information when you ask us to store it for you.

entry.title: Facebook's bite into TV
entry.summary:
By 2017, Facebook and YouTube's combined share of global online video spending will increase to 36% (from 34% in 2014).

"In contrast to YouTube, because users are logged into Facebook's service while viewing their newsfeed, Facebook can leverage all of a user's data to offer advertisers unmatched targeting at scale," DiClemente said.

Moreover, DiClemente noted, "YouTube audiences are more likely to be watching ads with sound, again due to users' intention of watching video content," whereas Facebook video ads autoplay in its users' feeds with the audio muted by default.

In the past two months, Facebook has inked deals to bring premium video to the service.

entry.title: Fin24.com | Facebook rolling out payments to friends feature
entry.summary:
The free service will be offered "in the coming months", according to a Facebook statement, and will put the huge social network in competition with services such as Square Cash and Venmo.

"Facebook processes more than one million transactions daily on the site and also handles all the payments processed on Messenger," the statement said.

entry.title: Penn State seeks frat members who posted nude photos online
entry.summary:
(AP) - A now-suspended Pennsylvania State University fraternity's Facebook posting of photos of nude and partly nude women, some of them asleep or passed out, is sad and offensive and could lead to some students being expelled, the university's president said Wednesday.

Police in State College, home to Penn State's main campus, are investigating allegations the fraternity operated a private Facebook page on which members shared frat house pictures of the women.

Police were tipped off about the Facebook account on Jan. 18 by a former fraternity member who shared printouts of some of the pictures.

entry.title: Will Payments On Facebook Be Successful?
entry.summary: Much like WeChat a sort of Facebook of China along with Alipay with their hundreds of millions of users to send money via instant message.

entry.title: Like Snapchat, Facebook will allow money tranfsers
entry.summary: NEW YORK -- Facebook's Messenger app will soon let you send your friends money, the latest in a crowded field of services aimed at an increasingly wireless and cashless generation.

entry.title: The latest way to pay someone from your phone: Facebook
entry.summary: Facebook users in the U.S. will soon be able to send their friends money using the social network's Messenger app, the company announced Tuesday, March 17, 2015.

entry.title: The latest way to pay someone from your phone: Facebook
entry.summary:
Facebook's entry, announced Tuesday, is free, works with debit cards and is available on Apple and Android mobile devices and on desktop computers.

Its payments systems are stored separately from other parts of the Facebook network and receive additional monitoring and control, the company said in a blog post Tuesday.

entry.title: Facebook to Let Users Send Money Via Messenger
entry.summary: The free feature will roll out over the next few months for users in the United States who access Facebook Messenger through desktop computers or Google Inc's Android and Apple Inc's iOS operating systems on mobile devices.

entry.title: Facebook to let users send money to friends via Messenger
entry.summary:
Facebook will likely expand internationally after the service becomes available to U.S. users over the coming months.

To help allay concerns about security, Facebook noted that it handles more than a million payments transactions on its site every day for its advertisers and game players.

entry.title: Penn State fraternity suspended for inappropriate Facebook photos
entry.summary: Students who feel they have been victims of the Facebook scandal or have information about it were encouraged by Penn State to contact campus authorities.

entry.title: Facebook to let US users send money to friends using Messenger app
Penn State frat suspended over Facebook page with nude photos of sleeping and passed-out women
entry.summary: Police say some Facebook posts also related to hazing and drug deals.

entry.title: Penn State frat suspended over Facebook page with nude pics of sleeping, passed-out women
entry.summary:
- A Penn State University fraternity was suspended for a year Tuesday after police began investigating allegations that members used a private, invitation-only Facebook page to post photos of nude and partly nude women, some apparently asleep or passed out.

According to the ex-fraternity member who went to police, a second page dubbed "2.0" was started in about April 2014 after a woman depicted on the first Facebook page, called "Covert Business Transactions," complained.

The informant said the woman was visiting the fraternity when a member accidentally left his Facebook page logged in, and she noticed a topless photograph of her had been posted to the group.

entry.title: American in UAE Facebook case may have charges dismissed
entry.summary: Pate's Facebook post has since been deleted.

entry.title: American in UAE Facebook case may have charges dismissed
Facebook Explains What Should Not Be Posted To The Social Network
entry.summary: Facebook's policies are not changing.

entry.title: Facebook clarifies post guidelines
entry.summary: Facebook has updated its "community standards" guidelines, giving users more clarity on acceptable posts - relating to nudity, violence, hate speech and other contentious topics.

entry.title: Is Facebook right to censor user content?
entry.summary: More than 1.4 billion people around the world use facebook every month.

entry.title: Facebook report shows rise in government requests for data
entry.summary: Facebook recorded a slight increase in government requests for account data globally in the second half of 2014, according to its Global Government Requests Report, which also includes information about content removal.

entry.title: Facebook clarifies rules on banned content
entry.summary: While Facebook has long forbidden groups it deems to be terrorist organizations from posting content on its service, the company specified that it will remove content that expresses support for such groups or praises their leaders.

entry.title: Facebook slaps ban on buttocks, buying drugs and celebrating crimes
entry.summary: As a result, Facebook said: 'We remove photographs of people displaying genitals or focusing in on fully exposed buttocks.

entry.title: Facebook explains what posts are not allowed on its network
entry.summary:
More than 80 percent of Facebook users are outside the U.S. and Canada.

Facebook users who believe that a particular page or content violates the site's standards can click a "report" link to notify Facebook.

Facebook restricts content in countries where it violates local laws, even if that content does not violate its community standards.

Separately, Facebook also released its latest report on requests it gets from governments worldwide, covering the second half of 2014.

entry.title: Facebook explains what posts are not allowed on its network
entry.summary: In a blog post Monday, Facebook said it is a challenge to maintain one set of standards that meet the needs of its entire community.

entry.title: Facebook clarifies guidelines on acceptable posts
entry.summary: Facebook at the same time released its report on government requests for user data in the second half of 2014, showing a modest uptick to 35,051 from 34,946 in the prior period.

entry.title: Facebook clarifies guidelines on acceptable posts
entry.summary:
The new guidelines say Facebook will take down "graphic images when they are shared for sadistic pleasure or to celebrate or glorify violence."

Facebook said earlier this year it was putting warnings on "graphic content," which would also be banned for users under 18.

entry.title: Facebook Clarifies Guidelines on Posts Containing Violence, Hate Speech, Nudity
entry.summary: "We saw a rise in content restriction requests from countries like Turkey and Russia, and declines in places like Pakistan," Facebook said.

entry.title: Facebook report shows slight rise in government requests for data
entry.summary:
Facebook said it restricted 9,707 pieces of content for violating local laws, 11% more than in the first half, with access restricted to 5,832 pieces in India and 3,624 in Turkey.

Bickert said Facebook challenges requests that appear to be "unreasonable" or "overbroad" and if a country requests content be removed because it is illegal, Facebook may restrict access only in that country.

Facebook, Microsoft, Yahoo and Google last year began publishing details about the number of government requests for data they receive.

entry.title: Facebook explains its updated Community Standards
entry.summary: Facebook said that the number in government requests for data and content restrictions have increased over the second half of 2014.

entry.title: Bits Blog: Facebook Clarifies Rules on What It Bans and Why
entry.summary:
One thing that has not changed: Facebook has no plans to automatically scan for and remove potentially offensive content, Ms. Bickert said.

Facebook will still rely on users to report violations of the standards.

But Facebook wants to take into account the full context of a post, Ms. Bickert said.

For example, a victim of a violent attack might post images on Facebook as a way of raising public awareness.

Ms. Bickert said that clarifying its rules helped not only Facebook users but also the people who reviewed possible violations to decide what was permissible.

entry.title: Judge: Man charged in Facebook fraud case apparently fled
entry.summary:
In 2010, Ceglia filed a multibillion-dollar lawsuit claiming that the 2003 software development contract included a provision entitling Ceglia to half ownership of Facebook in exchange for startup money.

Facebook lawyers have said the two had a contract but that references to Facebook were added for purposes of the lawsuit.

entry.title: Woman accused of Facebook chatting before crash that killed 3 kids
entry.summary: A western Wisconsin woman is accused of chatting on Facebook before a crash that killed three children, including her daughter and two nieces, in December 2013.

entry.title: U.S. contractor arrested in Abu Dhabi for Facebook posts
entry.summary: "I never even entertained the fact that I would wind up in prison out here for something I put on Facebook in the United States."

entry.title: Facebook exec, NBA team up to get men to 'lean in' for women
entry.summary:
Sandberg, Facebook's second-highest ranking executive behind CEO Mark Zuckerberg, is counting on the NBA's appeal to connect with millions of sports-loving men who haven't read her book.

Facebook is among a long list of major Silicon Valley companies with a dearth of women in engineering and other technical positions, where the best-paying jobs are found.

Women hold just 15 to 20 percent of the technology jobs at Google, Apple, Facebook and Yahoo, according to company disclosures made during the past nine months.

entry.title: Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg enlists NBA stars to persuade more men to support women's rights
entry.summary: Several technology companies, including Facebook Inc., Google Inc., Yahoo Inc. and Microsoft Corp., are backing a campaign that will be punctuated with (hashtag) LeanInTogether.

entry.title: Facebook posts about job land US contractor in Emirates jail
entry.summary:
Ryan Pate, a helicopter mechanic from Belleair Bluffs, Florida, took to Facebook after a dispute over sick leave with the company he was working for in the United Arab Emirates.

There was disagreement with his bosses about extending his leave to see a doctor, he said, and after a particularly unsatisfactory phone call with them, he took to a Facebook.

entry.title: Man accused of faking Facebook account for teen sex photos
entry.summary: He used the fake Facebook account to pretend to be another child the girl knew, regularly sending her pornographic images and engaging in sexually explicit chats with her before asking her to send him photos and videos of herself nude or engaging in sex acts, which she did, they said.

entry.title: Will Facebook make a car? Zuckerberg: Focus on the network
entry.summary:
Nonetheless, Facebook's goal of connecting people globally is "pretty broad," Zuckerberg said.

Facebook is also trying to get more people in developing countries online through its Internet.org push and developing its virtual-reality technology.

entry.title: Wanted Ohio man comments on sheriff?s Facebook, gets busted
entry.summary: "Andrew Dale Marcum will be off Facebook temporarily, because there is no social media access in the Butler County Jail," the department wrote.

entry.title: Domestic violence fugitive turns himself in after Facebook chat with sheriff
entry.summary: The Butler County Sheriff's Office posted three pictures of Marcum on Facebook on Tuesday saying that the 21-year-old was wanted on a slew of charges.

entry.title: Google, Facebook update contrasting plans to connect world
entry.summary:
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg arrives for a press conference at the Mobile World Congress, the world's largest mobile phone trade show in Barcelona, Spain, Monday, March 2, 2015.

Google and Facebook want more people online, searching around and clicking on ads.

And while Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Google Vice President Sundar Pichai say they might like to collaborate more, they are taking very different approaches to getting the world connected.

Internet.org is Facebook's fledgling effort to create new users in countries with little or low Internet use.

That is the reason why Internet.org does not include the WhatsApp messaging service, bought by Facebook last year.

Facebook is also experimenting with drones and satellites, however Zuckerberg said that the focus on high-tech fixes is "sexy" but not as important as helping local telecom operators grow their businesses.

entry.title: Iran's Guard monitored 8 million Facebook users
entry.summary:
It accuses Facebook of trying to attract users to "immoral pages" with "obscene content" through its suggestion system.

It says Facebook openly supports pages that violate the Islamic dress code for women.

entry.title: Woman: Ex-beau charged in Facebook killing told me he did it
entry.summary: Prosecutors accuse Kyle Dube 21, of Orono, of using a phony Facebook account to kidnap Nichole Cable, of Glenburn, and kill her in May 2013.

entry.title: French minister meets with Google, Facebook, Twitter
entry.summary:
Twitter and Facebook spokespeople said they do everything they can to stop material that incites violence but didn't say whether they would heed the minister's request for direct cooperation with French authorities.

"We regularly host ministers and other governmental officials from across the world at Facebook, and were happy to welcome Mr. Cazeneuve today," a Facebook spokesperson said.

entry.title: Catch-me-if-you-can criminal who taunted police on Facebook caught
entry.summary:
London: A wanted criminal who taunted British police on Facebook to "catch me if you can" has been arrested.

Just hours later a comment appeared, from James' profile, on the force's Facebook page saying: "Haha catch me if you can wont (sic) see me slipping".

Facebook users took delight at the news - which received more than 600 likes on Gwent Police's page.
